citeinfo.origin: Department of Commerce (DOC), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Ocean Service (NOS), Office for Coastal Management (OCM)
citeinfo.title: Census Statistics (County)

descript.abstract: Data from the 2010 Decennial Census and the 2012 - 2016 five year estimates from the American Community Survey were joined to TIGER/Line shapefiles of US coastal counties produced by the Census Bureau to produce this visual representation of select census statistics. The Decennial Census is a nation wide survey conducted every tenth year by the U.S. Census Bureau as mandated by U.S. The Constitution for the purpose of establishing an accurate count of the country's population. The results, published at the end of each survey year, are primarily used by the government to allocate funds and apportion seats in the U.S. House of Representatives. Until 2000, one in every 6 households received a "long form" of the Decennial Census to collect additional social, housing and economic information, but the long form was discontinued after the 2000 Decennial Census. The continuing need for timely, nationally consistent information on the topics formerly included in the long form lead the Census Bureau to develop the American Community Survey (ACS) in 2005. The ACS is an ongoing survey program which randomly samples about 3.5 million households throughout the year. Data from the ACS is published in several formats each fall. In addition to the fifty States, the Census Bureau treats the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and each of the Island Areas (American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, Guam, and the U.S. Virgin Islands) as the statistical equivalents of States for the purpose of data presentation. Similarly, there are also several independednt cities in the New England area identified by law which the Census Bureau treats as county equvalents for Census purposed; a subset of these have been included based on their coastal proximity. Some county level data was not reported by the Decennial Census or the ACS in the US territories and therefore does not appear in this product. Additional information about the Decennial Census and the American Community Survey is available at https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys.html.
descript.purpose: To support coastal and ocean planning and other activities pursuant to the Energy Policy Act, Coastal Zone Management Act, Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act, National Environmental Policy Act, Rivers and Harbors Act and the Submerged Lands Act.

idinfo.useconst: These data are intended for coastal and ocean planning. Not for navigation. http://www.marinecadastre.gov/about/disclaimer.html
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.4.1.5713

attracc.attraccr: The attributes in this dataset are believed to be accurate. For ACS data: Data are based on a sample and are subject to sampling variability. The degree of uncertainty for an estimate arising from sampling variability is represented through the use of a margin of error (margin of error was omitted from this product but can be found in the original source data). In addition to sampling variability, the ACS estimates are subject to nonsampling error. The effect of nonsampling error is not represented in these tables. For additional information on the accuracy of ACS data please see https://www2.census.gov/programs-surveys/acs/tech_docs/accuracy/MultiyearACSAccuracyofData2016.pdf. For Census data: While it is impossible to completely eliminate nonsampling error from an operation as large and complex as the decennial census, the Census Bureau attempts to control the sources of such error during the collection and processing operations. For additional information on decennial census methodology, accuracy and error please consult "2010 Census Demographic Profile Summary File", Chapter 5 - Operational Overview and Accuracy of the Data (https://www2.census.gov/programs-surveys/acs/tech_docs/accuracy/MultiyearACSAccuracyofData2016.pdf).

dataqual.logic: These data are believed to be logically consistent. Geometry is topologically clean.
dataqual.complete: Spatial and attribute properties are believed to be complete, although attribute information has been simplified. Geometric thresholds from original data are preserved. No tests have been completed for exhaustiveness. For ACS data: When information is missing or inconsistent, the Census Bureau logically assigns an acceptable value using the response to a related question or questions. If a logical assignment is not possible, data are filled using a statistical process called allocation, which uses a similar individual or household to provide a donor value. The "Allocated" section is the number of respondents who received an allocated value for a particular subject. For Census data: while it is impossible to completely eliminate nonsampling error from an operation as large and complex as the decennial census, the Census Bureau attempts to control the sources of such error during the collection and processing operations. For additional information on decennial census methodology, accuracy and error please consult "2010 Census Demographic Profile Summary File", Chapter 5 - Operational Overview and Accuracy of the Data (https://www2.census.gov/programs-surveys/acs/tech_docs/accuracy/MultiyearACSAccuracyofData2016.pdf).

horizpa.horizpar: Maximum scale of intended use is 1:80,000.

citeinfo.origin: Office for Coastal Management, NOAA Office for Coastal Management, Department of Commerce (DOC), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Ocean Service (NOS), Office for Coastal Management (OCM)
citeinfo.title: Coastal Counties

pubinfo.publish: Office for Coastal Management, NOAA Office for Coastal Management, Department of Commerce (DOC), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Ocean Service (NOS), Office for Coastal Management (OCM)

srcinfo.srccontr: polygon features joined to census and ACS data

procstep.procdesc: Download Census and ACS data from American Factfinder as comma-delimited (*.csv) documents. Delete any superfluous attributes.

Merge select omitted independent cities from TIGER/Line Shape with Coastal Counties (Washington DC, Fairfax city, Falls Church city, Fredricksburg city, Manassas city, Manassas Park city, Richmond city, and Colonial Heights city). Utilize topology to align polygon edges.

Join the downloaded tables to the updated Coastal Counties layer using the County FIPS attribute to copy the median household income from the ACS table and the total population and total housing units from the Census table into the associated attributes in the Coastal Counties layer.
